results.title: Backdrop for a play
results.brief_description: Shows the activities of a group of children who prepare thw backdrop, scenery and costumes and act out the fairy tale “Puss in Boots”, against a background of a deserted colonial mansion in the midlands of Tasmania.

results.title: Babe: pig in the city
results.brief_description: The sequel to the 1995 surprise hit ‘Babe’ moves the action of the first film into the vast unknown of a sprawling metropolis. Along with the radical change comes a surprisingly dark undertone. What launches Babe’s adventure is an unfortunate well accident involving farmer Hoggett. Babe, along with Mrs Hoggett, must then head into the big city to drum up money and save the farm from bankruptcy. Once there the native duo are separated and Babe finds himself in a strange boarding house for animals. Although critics feared the film might have been too intense for kids, Miller’s film is full of compassion, pathos and unexpected poignanacy.

results.title: Babar: The City of Elephants
results.creator_credit: Raymond Jafelice, Clive A Smith, Michael Hirsh and Patricia Loubert
results.brief_description: Babar Returns - Babar leaves the old lady and the city to return to the jungle so that he can bring the other elephants his newfound knowledge. But he finds that they resist trying any of his new ideas. “City of the Elephants” - As the elephants new king, Babar’s first decree is to build a city. However, he must contend with Lord Rataxes, who is also trying to build a city, as well as his own obsession to see his city completed on time. Rated: G

results.title: Baba Yaga: a Russian fairy tale
results.brief_description: Presented as an on-line interactive storybook to read page by page with silhouetted illustrations, this Russian fairy tale tells the story of Vasilissa, her evil stepmother and Baba Yaga, the wicked witch who lives deep in the forest.

results.title: The Mandala garden
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Back yard permaculture”.
In less than four hours, permaculturist Robyn Francis transforms an area of vigorous lawn into a ready-to-plant, landscaped garden without the agonies of digging, turning the soil or removing the weeds. Vegetables, herbs and flowers are companion planted for ease of maintenance and harvest and in six weeks, the first delights of the garden are ready for picking. This gardening technique will suit any soil or climate.

results.title: Customer Relations in Practice
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: More awkward customers (NP)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Customer Relations in Practice”.
Emphasises the importance of professional knowledge of an organisation’s stocks or services in dealing with difficult customers. Highlights the customer who parades their knowledge, the silent customer who cannot communicate his needs and the finicky customer who requires every detail. Features John Cleese, Anghared Rees, Patricia Routledge, Bernard Cribbins and Lyn Redgrave. FOR USE ONLY IN A DOMESTIC SITUATION OR FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES ONLY.

results.title: Awkward customers (NP)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Customer Relations in Practice”.
John Cleese and Angharad Rees play two sales assistants who demonstrate how to handle awkward customers. Shows the customer in a temper, the compulsive talker and the rude, aggressive and offensive customer. John Barron, June Whitfield and George A. Cooper appear as the awkward customers. FOR USE ONLY IN A DOMESTIC SITUATION OR FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES ONLY.

results.title: Back to the past (April 2006)
results.brief_description:
“Back to the Past” is a program for primary schools to learn scripting, production and performance skills using virtual set technology. Starring Charles “Bud Tingwell ” as a time travelling scientist, BTTP sends students back in time to historical Melbourne using archival footage, animation and green screen technology.
Back to the Past or “Screening Melbourne” is designed to encourage students to develop an appreciation for the art and the craft behind moving image in its many forms by developing their ability to think beyond the screen. In the program Students become actors in a sci-fi time travel film story during a blue-screen workshop that allows them to place themselves in a historical Melbourne setting, engage with a screening program featuring historical Melbourne footage and participate in a related discussion
learn some simple editing skills while they create a digital ‘Melbourne travelogue’
Back to the Past aims to develop students’ understanding of ways in which film-makers create screen texts to target particular audiences. Students in Years 3-4 learn about concepts related to camera use such as framing, shot types, and angles as well as some of the features of documentary and blue-screen technology.
